Radio Free Europe has an interview with a female news reporter from a moderate Iranian newspaper. Her identity is protected. Excerpt:
 
 -----------
 
 RFE/RL: What happened in Iran or what is happening in Iran? Some call it a coup, while others describe it as an epic and a "people's election." What is your view as a journalist who is in Tehran?
 
 Iranian Journalist: The important event that took place in Iran is that it wasn't an election; it was a coup d'etat. [They] stole 24 million votes of the nation and took them away for themselves. If there were really a winner, they would have to celebrate, but instead they beat people. They performed a coup, but they don't call it a coup.
 
 RFE/RL: What are the indications?
 
 Journalist: Please don't use the word "fraud" because it is mitigation of what has happened in Iran. Fraud is what was happening in the past 30 years. This is not fraud. They haven't [counted ] people's votes. Using the word fraud is like calling a deep cut a small scratch. There was no fraud; it was a coup.
 
 RFE/RL: Please explain why you call it a coup. Based on what? 
 
 Journalist: Based on the military atmosphere that is now ruling [in the country], based on the threats against senior officials in the country. What are the elements of a coup in the world? Just now as we're speaking, [Mahmud Ahmadinejad] said I'll clean the Iranian establishment of all these corrupted elements. [If this isn't] a coup, then what is it?
 
 Coup means that right now they're beating people in the streets. A coup means they didn't even count people's votes. They announced the results without opening the ballot boxes. It was sent as a circular to the state television, which announced it. Is it so difficult for the world to understand this? 
 
 RFE/RL: How do you think the world should react to what has happened in Iran and what is happening right now -- the protests and the crackdown?
 
 Journalist: Recognizing Iran's election as an election is a crime against democracy. The countries that have fought for democracy, countries that talk about democracy, if they accept this, they're betraying themselves. This was not an election. If they accept this, it means they've put democracy under question. They've launched a coup under the cover of democracy.
 
 This is a very important event. Just look at what the indications for a coup are. Last night, [cellphone] lines were cut; we can't send SMSs. We can't check our e-mails. We can't keep in touch on Facebook. If this was a real election, then why [these measures]? [People] are responding to this in the streets. People were being beaten up in the streets until 4 a.m. They had gone out to be beaten. Everyone is upset and [holding back tears].
 
 (full interview at link)
 
 'From Now On, Democracy Doesn't Exist Anymore' - Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty 2009

I think both of Bush's elections were invalid, though 2000 was pretty blatant. That being behind us, though, it's astounding the degree to which Ahmadinejad is thumbing his nose in the face of democracy. Heck, they didn't even try to make it look close. They have no monitoring body. Plus, they didn't count boxes upon boxes of votes, if I am understanding the story correctly, and while claiming to have counted 40 million paper ballots in 2 hours after the polls closed. (Canada is remarkable for being able to hand count their paper ballots for a national election in 4 days.) I guess the rough equivalent, in the U.S., would be if they counted the votes for 2 or 3 states heavily known to be one candidate's favor, and then, declared victory and ignored all the rest.
 
 In the U.S., the big issue, to me, in holding valid elections, is having a return to simple paper ballots publicly counted (like, in Canada, for example). Because I think computerized election is so open to corruption. And with paper ballots, when you do monitor elections, the evidence is right there.
 
 Given that they have paper ballots, it seems there should be some impartial monitoring body to publicly recount -- and account for -- all the votes. But considering that recounts are challenging even in our elections (with whoever's ahead fighting it), and Iran is a country where they stone people to death, it seems unlikely short of some unusual international feat.
 
 Ahamadinajad seems plagued with an extraordinary inadequacy complex that he is trying to compensate for. Like many dictators. And of course, his thumbing the nose at blatant voting evidence is no different than the way he thumbs his nose at blatant evidence for other things ...

I think both of Bush's elections were invalid, though 2000 was pretty blatant. That being behind us, though, it's astounding the degree to which Ahmadinejad is thumbing his nose in the face of democracy. Heck, they didn't even try to make it look close. They have no monitoring body. Plus, they didn't count boxes upon boxes of votes, if I am understanding the story correctly, and while claiming to have counted 40 million paper ballots in 2 hours after the polls closed. (Canada is remarkable for being able to hand count their paper ballots for a national election in 4 days.) 

 
 It all depends on how many people you have counting. In the UK, we normally get the first results within the hour (a couple of constituencies in urban areas compete to get the first results in) and enough results to tell who won within 12 hours of the polls closing. A well organised ballot with only a few candidates, and sufficient counters, could be completed within a relatively small time scale, paper ballots or no. Canada is huge, just getting ballot boxes from remote areas will take time (complete UK results are usually delayed by Eilean Siar and Orkney & Shetland)

I was reading in the latest issue of The New Scientist one of the letters to the editor of the magazine, in it the writer says :
 
 “I have taught evolution as part of my geology courses for 40 years and have become very pessimistic about American values. The average American is very religious and militaristic —feelings driven by fear, superstition and ignorance.”
 
 I would add that the militaristic feelings of the populace have made it easy for the ruling classes to make the USA the super-interventionist power of the XXth century and so far this one. What is ironic, for most Americans look only at their navels and think the sun shines out of their anuses illuminating the rest of creation. So the irony is that the people with their head stuck up their ‘you know what’, are at the same time the ones roaming the world like crazy vigilantes. This lethal combination of inward looking people patrolling blindly the world is the cause of US interventionism having done and doing more harm than good and created a feeling of anti-Americanism world wide. The ugliest manifestation of which was 9/11.
 
 Who cares about imposing democracy in Iraq? It won’t last long. And leave the Iranians alone. Those cultures have been anti-democratic for thousands of years and maybe if they had subjugated the Greeks we wouldn’t have democracy now.

 Far be for me or anyone else to impose democracy on Iran. I was against that notion insofar as Iraq was concerned, too. Democracy has to come from within a nation, from the nation's people -- not another nation's -- or it is not democracy. Oxymoronic, that is.
 
 I agree that our country has been quite militaristic. We pour lots of money into the military budget, so it follows, of course. And this was a direct result of the Second World War. Now, we take the heat from countries and peoples who, at the same time, rely on that military might, or have greatly relied, while they have financial advantages for their nations otherwise, and no excuse not to put their money into those other endeavors, like healthcare, for example. 
 
 HP is carrying a heck of lot photographs of the demonstrations inside the country. Their signs (one said he was Nazi and a Fascist, so they're not into self-consciously and apologetically sc*****g themselves about using the N or F words -- when the shoe fits, hey -- less like Americans and more like the French) and their massively and spontaneously organized efforts (using just Twitter, they say!) demonstrate that they are, rather, very very democratically oriented as a people. Even moreso than in the U.S. (where we should all get on Twitter and, for example, overthrow the health care system -- but Americans are so *divorced* from one another when it comes to concerted social action related to matters of everyday importance -- a big problem if you want to have a democracy). Of course, media sources can distort the magnitude of unrest, and that media source, too, may well be in bed with the defense contractors, but it really looks like Iran wants a changing of the guard.
 
 I wouldn't go to war with them over their government, but I hope they get what they want, if that's what's going on. Just like our presidential elections affect the rest of the planet, theirs do, as well. In Europe, they stayed up around the clock, watching the American returns and praying that it wasn't going to be the Republicans going in, yet again. I was glad the world was engaged about our process. So unlike yourself, I imagine many Iranians would feel similarly, as long as it's not in the spirit of inteference, of GWB going into Iraq. There is a difference, though I suppose, as soon as you're identified as American or European or Australian, your motives suspect insofar as world conquest and blood lust are concerned.
 
 However, I wouldn't let that stop me from expressing myself, as an individual, or as a citizen of the world. Nor should I blind myself to the ambitions of other human beings, who, like anyone else, are but human. For I have nothing to apologize for, being no more than one person born as one miniscule of a miniscule of a miniscule of a (etc) speck in the vast sweep of time and space and wonder.

 I'm very wary of French attitudes to religious expression, and particularly in this case as the likely result if women are being forced to wear the burkha is that they won't be permitted to leave the house at all if they're not allowed t wear it.

I'm very wary of French attitudes to religious expression, and particularly in this case as the likely result if women are being forced to wear the burkha is that they won't be permitted to leave the house at all if they're not allowed t wear it.

 
 French society is even more secular than the U.S., but my understanding is that they are indiscriminately thus. For example, you can't wear a hijab to a public school, but you can't wear a cross or a Star of David, either. 
 
 I don't know how far they want to take this dress code -- some of the women among the hardline demonstrators in Iran, for example, look like they're in nuns' habits. The garments, a little less bulky, and the face shows. (Of course, there must be a lot of nuns in France, but then again, the government is getting fed up with the Church. Take, for example, the show down with the Pope and their public health officials over AIDS and condoms. I give them a lot of credit for not mincing words with the religious authorities over that.)
 
 You couldn't do this legally in the U.S., I guess, short of public places like airports or banks. But I would hardly object to the French exercising their laws in this respect, as I must restrain my desire to interfere with other countries doing much worse -- that is, what is happening presently in Iran, as we politely "non-interfere" -- or do "the prime directive" (if you followed Star Trek at all in the U.K.).
 
 My guess is that hardline chauvinists would have to relent because otherwise no one would do their shopping and errands. And in France, one must go shopping each day.
 
 That is, they'd adapt. And of course, it's illegal in France (like the States or the U.K.) to keep an adult against their will in a house or apartment. Equivalent to kidnapping.

I don't see it as my job to pass judgement on the genuineness of someone's religious expression and the values they expect of their family, unless they are demonstrably damaging.
 
 Whilst the French position is theoretically neutral, it doesn't take account of the fact that there are no Christian denominations that require the wearing of a crucifix, but both Muslims and Jews have religious requirements for how they dress. The French secular system is dangerous and fosters intolerance of difference. There is a reason fascists do better in France than elsewhere in Europe. Studies have shown underlying racism is a serious problem in France. They don't have any monitoring of ethnic minority employment or discrimination because they law says that ethnicity doesn't exist. This is fine in principle, but what it means is that people with French names get jobs where identically qualified people with Arab Muslim names do not, and there is no official way of dealing with it.

 The cross is very important to Christians in the U.S. It may not be imposed as a formal rule, but I know a number of Christians who feel religiously required, almost as if it were. There is a tremendous feeling of offense at the idea of not being able to wear it, for example, as a student -- or even among some teachers -- in a public school. Not an issue in France -- why? Because it's not such a big deal for human beings to adapt in this respect. They may squawk a lot at first, but they are not being tortured. Whether it's a cross, a hijab, or a Star of David. And if it is such torture, well, there's private school. One thing no one can say, however, is that someone has been discriminated against.
 
 
The French secular system is dangerous and fosters intolerance of difference.

 I don't know that fascists necessarily do better in France than elsewhere in Europe. I've read about some pretty intense fascists in the U.K. and Germany and Italy, for example. We have some very sick ones here, too.
 
 I recognize that racism exists in France, as it does in many places. I do agree that fascism and racism go hand in hand, and can be an issue in all this -- as in Islamaphobia and forms of ethnocentrism. 
 
 I think, however, it's important to recognize that the burkha is fascistic and sexist. One can only bend over so far in sensitivity to religion before religion is walking all over you and your rights.
 
 This reminds me of the debate around FGM. I think, at some point, you just have to say, it's time to step into the 21st century.
 
 This is not about religion and faith and culture (though, at the same time, it very much is). IOW, it's being used an excuse to violate human rights.

FGM is vastly different because it has a permanent irreversible and demonstrably damaging effect and the procedure itself is risky.
 
 And yes, fascists do better in France than other countries. The BNP (the largest fascist party in the UK) has never won seat in parliament, and has never managed so much as 1% in a general election (0.74% at the last election). Even at a European election under Proportional Representation, amid disgust and anger with the political class in this country, and widespread anti-europe sentiment, they could only scrape together 6.2% of the very low turnout, coming in 6th behind the Green Party. In France, on the other hand, Front Nationale leader le Penn made it through to the run off in the Presidential election in 2002, achieving 25% of the vote, and even in the most recent national assembly elections registered over a million votes.

Getting back to the Iranian elections (and away from Winston's personal "stuff"), I think about 17 deaths have been recorded thus far, and now, the government is cracking down even more on the press, with at least 24 reporters arrested in Iran, including foreign journalists. Excerpt from AP article,
 
 -----------------
 
 Among those detained were the head of the Association of Iranian Journalists and a Canadian reporter for Newsweek. The British Broadcasting Corporation's correspondent has been ordered to leave the country.
 
 "It's becoming more and more problematic for journalists," said Benoit Hervieu of Paris-based Reporters Without Borders, also known by its French acronym RSF.
 
 The group released the names of 23 Iranian journalists, editors and bloggers arrested since June 14, and says it has lost contact with several others believed detained or in hiding. Hervieu said RSF verified each arrest via its network of reporters and activists in Iran.
 
 Newsweek said in a statement later that its correspondent Maziar Bahari, a Canadian citizen, was detained without charge Sunday morning and has not been heard from since. Newsweek defended his coverage of Iran as "fair and nuanced" and called for his release.
 
 In most cases, the reasons behind the detentions remain unclear.
 
 t r u t h o u t | At Least 24 Reporters Arrested in Iran
 
 -----------------
 
 JoBennett, if you peek into healthcare, we've touched on the subject of conservatism in France. I think I have soundly defeated any notion that it's on the rise there, but I'd be interested in your response relative to that topic. Thinking back on what you've said (though it's gotten heated at moments and the sexist and pathetic WS quips haven't helped), I think France may have a tradition of militancy that may make a right-wing more unapologetically visible at times, though the country itself, for the most part, is fairly left. But again, I don't see this right wing as related to France's secularism. The French have their own way of dealing with diversity, just as we do in the U.S. (and I can't speak for the U.K.). I see us (U.S. and France, that is) as having similar goals, but perhaps approaches from different ends of a spectrum. With what France does, as likely best for France. As what the States attempts, best for us. After all, our countries are very different, too. But I will be curious to see how that develops because we have yet (and perhaps, never) to encounter some of the same issues in America. For example, I can only recall one time seeing a woman in a full burkha. And to tell you the truth, here in the U.S., it was a rather chilling sight. But then again, I am a female poster. And I take it, you are not. Years ago, too, during the Iranian hostage crisis, I knew an Iranian woman exiled here in the States. She was a pro-democracy person who adopted western ways, and was essentially a secular Muslim. Kind of the equivalent of a Christmas Christian in the U.S. Fortunately, she did not have to return. But that possibility, which loomed for a while, was a very serious issue. Because of the nature of her rights -- or lack thereof -- she did not have them in important ways -- under her government. Which is very, very different than France or America or the U.K. It is a religious theocracy. An authoritarian and nationalistic dictatorship. A fascist state. Where a young, beautiful and innocent female philosophy student, standing on a corner with her father, dressed in western clothing, can be shot through the heart by a government sniper and killed right there in the street. Ask WS what they did to women wearing certain clothing during Pinochet's military coup d'etat that he supported as a student in Chile because his father was a right-wing dilettante. If he is honest enough to tell you. And in the name of faith, not secularism. Ask him what one of Pinochet's first acts were, concerning women's right to choose, when abortion was already outlawed in Chile, except when the mother's life was in danger. In the name of faith, not secularism.

BBC is carrying a statement made by Neda Agha-Solton's fiancee (the young woman who was shot by militia). The family was not allowed by the authorities to have a memorial service. If I follow this story correctly, it appears too that the government is digging graves for people they anticipate being killed. (There's a photograph at the website.)
